title-group.article-title: Continuous crack modeling in piezoelectrically driven vibrations of an Euler–Bernoulli beam

abstract.p: One of the main objectives of the structural health monitoring community is to continuously monitor the integrity of a structure by embedding sensors and actuators into the structure. A piezoelectrically driven beam is considered in the present work and the effect of the growth of a single crack on the vibratory characteristics of the beam is studied. It is shown that in order to combine the effect of a crack and the piezoceramic (PZT) actuator into the modeling, available formulations of the mode shapes of the cracked beam, such as modeling the beam as a bi-section connected with a rotational spring, are not applicable as they are not twice differentiable. A new formulation of the mode shapes of the cracked beam is introduced here by applying the Rayleigh–Ritz method. The effect of location and depth of the crack on the vibratory response of the beam is modeled through formulating the loss of energy due to the presence of the crack, which is approximated here as a massless rotational spring. It is shown that the proposed crack modeling provides a close approximation of the mode shapes of the cracked beam. This modeling approach is beneficial as it provides twice-differentiable mode shapes for the cracked beam and can be used as trial functions in the assumed mode approximations. Numerical analysis is also provided for various design parameters, such as crack depth and position and the location of the PZT patch.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Structural health monitoring (SHM) has attracted increasing interest during the past few decades for monitoring the integrity of civil infrastructures and aerospace systems. What distinguishes SHM from the conventional nondestructive evaluations (NDEs) is the continuous monitoring of the structure, which is done through embedding transducers, such as piezoceramic (PZT) patches, into the structure. The presence of these sensors and actuators introduces added mass and electro-mechanical coupling into the structure, altering the vibratory characteristics of the system. Therefore, in order to have a complete modeling of the monitored structure, the effect of presence of these parameters needs to be considered, as well as damage growth in the structure.

To date, there have been numerous approaches to modeling damage, in particular cracks, in beam-like structures (Adams et al., 1978; Narkis, 1994; Afshari et al., 2009; Faverjon and Sinou, 2009; Prasad et al., 2010). A crack changes the mode shapes and reduces the resonance frequency of the beam, as it changes the local stiffness of the beam at the location of the crack. Initiation and growth of single or multiple cracks in a beam, therefore, may be monitored by studying the variations in the beam’s resonant frequency and mode shapes. Therefore, analytical modeling of the relation between the resonance frequency of the beam and different parameters of location and severity of the crack would be helpful in SHM applications. One of the first papers on analytical modeling of the effect of the presence of a crack on the vibration-based response of a beam studied the mode shapes and resonant frequencies of an Euler–Bernoulli beam with one or more symmetric cracks (Christides and Barr, 1984). In this modeling, a stress field is formulated experimentally and it assumed to decrease exponentially moving away from the crack along the length of the beam. Using the stress distribution formulations, the first mode shape of a simply supported Euler–Bernoulli beam with a symmetric pair of cracks at the mid-span is formulated. Presence and growth of a crack in a vibrating beam was also modeled as the resultant reduction in the stiffness of the beam at the place of the crack. Freund and Herrmann (1976) formulated this resultant stiffness by applying fracture mechanics formulations, the stress intensity factor and the elastic deformation energy. This form of modeling the crack in a beam was later combined with various beam formulations in order to analytically study the vibration-based response and mode shapes of a cracked beam. Chondros and Dimarogonas (1998) and Chondros et al. (1998) used the resultant stiffness crack modeling and applied the Hu–Washizu–Barr variational formulations in formulating the vibration-based response of a beam with a single-edge crack. Ostachowicz and Krawczuk (1991) applied the resultant crack stiffness formulation and modeled the crack as a massless rotational spring. They were among the first to model the cracked beam as a bi-section, connected at the crack location with a torsional spring. Compatibility conditions are applied at the crack location to formulate the mode shapes of the cracked beam. Their studies were limited to the numerical analysis of a cantilever beam with multiple, single-edged cracks. The concept of crack modeling as a massless rotational spring connecting the two sections of the beam was later used in different references for various support conditions, numbers of cracks and loadings of the beam. These studies were initially done numerically for Euler–Bernoulli and Timoshenko beams with single or multiple cracks. Later, closed-form expressions of the mode shapes and resonant frequencies of a vibrating cracked beam were formulated for different boundary conditions and crack specifications (Khiem and Lien, 2001; Fernandez-Saez and Navarro, 2002; Li, 2003; Aydin, 2008). This form of modeling of the vibrations and mode shapes of a cracked beam has also been applied to the identification (i.e. determining the location and size) of a crack in a vibrating beam. Closed-form expressions of the location and severity of the crack were provided for different support conditions of the beam (Morassi, 1993; Hasan, 1995; Dilena and Morassi, 2004). The early works on the vibration-based response of a cracked beam assume a nonbreathing crack in order to avoid nonlinear terms and complexity added to the modeling of the structure. In recent years, however, more work has been focused on the effect of the opening and closing of the crack on the vibration response of a cracked beam (Chatterjee, 2010; Rezaee and Hassannejad, 2011).

For continuous monitoring of the integrity of a structure and detecting the initiation and growth of a damage in it, which is one of the main objectives of SHM, the structure needs to be integrated with transducers, such as surface-bonded PZT patches. The effect of these PZT actuators on the vibration-based response of a structure, here a beam, also needs to be considered in the analytical modeling. This modeling is also helpful in controlling the effect of variations in the environmental parameters, such as temperature and humidity fluctuations, on the beams’ dynamic behavior. The presence of the PZT transducers changes the mass and stiffness of the beam due to the added layer of material. It also affects the vibratory characteristics of the beam through the electro-mechanical coupling with the structure. Various models have been used for modeling the static and dynamic coupling between PZT and the beam (Bailey and Hubbard, 1985; Crawley and De Luis, 1987; Chaudhry and Rogers, 1994; Strambi et al., 1995). The pin-force model is one of the early models for the interaction between a beam and surface-bonded PZT actuators. In this model, which assumes a perfect bonding between PZT and the beam, the effect of PZT is replaced with two concentrated moments applied at the two edges of the actuator (see, for instance, Barboni et al., 2000). Another modeling approach is to integrate constitutive equations of the PZT active layer into formulating the equation of motion of the beam (Leo, 2007; Erturk and Inman, 2011).

In the present paper, a piezoelectrically driven beam is considered and the effect of growth of a single crack on the vibratory characteristics of the beam is studied. The single fatigue crack is modeled as a massless rotational spring and the effect of the presence of the surface-bonded PZT layer is modeled by applying the linear PZT constitutive relations and the assumed mode method. It is shown that the closed-form formulations of the mode shapes of the cracked beam, as presented by Khiem and Lien (2001) and referred to as the ‘reference modeling’ in the following sections of the present work, are not applicable to the assumed mode method. Here, mode shapes of the cracked beam are approximated by applying the Rayleigh–Ritz method. The effect of the crack on the vibratory response of the beam is modeled through formulating the loss of energy due to the presence of the crack, which is modeled here as a massless rotational spring. The proposed approximate mode shapes of the cracked beam and the associated resonant frequencies are numerically compared to that of the reference modeling of the cracked beam. This modeling approach is beneficial, as it provides twice-differentiable mode shapes for the cracked beam and can be used as trial functions in the assumed mode approximation for different applications. Numerical analysis is also provided for various design parameters of crack position and depth and location of the PZT patch for the entire structure. Discussions of the numerical results and conclusions are then presented.

sec.title: 2. Theory and modeling
sec.p: The beam studied here is assumed to be a uniform Euler–Bernoulli beam having a single fatigue crack at a distance of xc from the beginning of the beam. The beam is assumed to have length L, width b, thickness hb and a uniform cross section along the beam. The beam is studied for two different support conditions: fixed–fixed and simply supported on both ends. The transverse displacement of the beam in the y-direction depends on the position along the length of the beam, x, and time and is denoted as v(x,t). For simplicity in the modeling, the fatigue crack is assumed to be nonbreathing during the deformations of the beam, that is, the crack does not open and close during vibration. The crack is also assumed to be over the entire width of the beam and only part-way through (i.e. a surface crack). It is assumed that the beam is actuated using a surface-bonded PZT actuator with the length of La, width of b and thickness of ha, attached at the location x1a from the start of the beam.

The goal of the present paper is to formulate the mode shapes of the cracked beam with the attached, active PZT actuator and investigate how the presence and growth of the crack will change the resonant frequencies of the beam. Moreover, the optimal placement of the PZT actuator for crack detection is studied here, assuming that the crack is not formed under the PZT patch. This modeling can be used in studying and compensating for the effect of environmental variations in the structure’s parameters during SHM.

For the cracked beam actuated with the PZT layer, different modeling parameters need to be considered. The effect of the PZT actuator as an added layer and the electro-mechanical coupling between the active PZT and the beam is one of these modeling factors. The effect of the presence and growth of the crack, boundary conditions of the vibrating beam and the inertial and elastic effects of the beam are others factors to be included in the complete modeling of the system shown in Figure 1. The assumed mode method is applied to the energy formulations and, together with applying Lagrange equations, the temporal equation of the vibrating structure with the PZT is formulated, as presented in the following. Figure 1.
Beam with a single fatigue crack under piezoceramic (PZT) actuation.

sec.title: 2.1. Transverse vibrations of the PZT-driven, cracked beam
sec.p: In order to formulate the equation of motion of the beam of Figure 1, Lagrange equations and the assumed mode method are applied here. Total strain energy of the beam together with the PZT patch is formulated as (1)π=12∫∫∫VbeamσxxbɛxxbdVbeam+12∫∫∫VPZTσxxpɛxxpdVPZT where σxxb and ɛxxb are the stress and strain components related to the lateral displacement of v(x,t) for the Euler–Bernoulli beam as (2)ɛxxb=-y∂2v(x,t)∂x2σxxb=-Eby∂2v(x,t)∂x2 where Eb is the modulus of elasticity of the beam.

Considering the linear PZT constitutive relations, the stress and strain related to the PZT are formulated as (Leo, 2007) (3)σxxp=c11ES1-e31E3ɛxxp=S1=-y∂2v(x,t)∂x2 where c11E, e31 and E3 are modulus of elasticity of the PZT at constant electric field, piezoelectric stress constant and the electric field across the electrodes of the PZT, respectively. The relations between the electric field and the applied voltage V(t), and between e31 and the piezoelectric strain constant of d31 are (4)E3=V(t)hae31=c11Ed31

Substituting the strain and stress terms into Equation (1), the strain energy may be simplified as (5)π=12∫0LEbIb(∂2v(x,t)∂x2)2dx+12∫x1ax2ac11EIp(∂2v(x,t)∂x2)2dx +12∫x1ax2aJpV(t)∂2v(x,t)∂x2dx where x2a=x1a+La, Jp=e31b(hb+ha)/2, and Ib and Ip are the area moments of inertia of the beam and the PZT layer, respectively, with respect to the z-axis formulated as (6)Ib=112bhb3Ip=13bha3+14bhahb(hb+2ha)

Total kinetic energy of the beam together with the PZT layer is formulated as (7)T=12∫∫∫Vbeamρb(∂v(x,t)∂t)2dVbeam +12∫∫∫VPZTρa(∂v(x,t)∂t)2dVPZT which may be simplified as (8)T=12∫0L(ρA)(x)(∂v(x,t)∂t)2dx where (9)(ρA)(x)=ρhbb+ρahab[H(x-x1a)H(x2a-x)]

Using the assumed mode approximation method, the transverse deflection of the vibrating beam, under the actuation of a surface-bonded PZT patch, will be (Meirovitch, 1967) (10)v(x,t)=∑i=1naXi(x)qi(t) where Xi(x) represents admissible functions, satisfying the geometric boundary conditions of the vibrating beam and qi(t) represents the corresponding unknown, time-dependent generalized coordinates. Substituting v(x,t) of Equation (10) into formulations of the strain and kinetic energies yields (11)π=12∑i=1na∑l=1na[qi(t)ql(t)Kil+qi(t)V(t)ηi]T=12∑i=1na∑l=1naq·i(t)q·l(t)Mil where (12)Kil=∫0L(EI)(x)Xi″(x)Xl″(x)dxηi=∫x1ax2aJpXi″(x)dxMil=∫0L(ρA)(x)Xi(x)Xl(x)dx with (13)(EI)(x)=EbIb+c11EIpH(x-x1a)H(x2a-x)
The Lagrange equations can be expressed as (14)ddt(∂T∂q·j)-∂T∂qj+∂π∂qj=0

By substituting the strain and kinetic energies of Equation (11) into the Lagrange’s equation, the temporal equation of the discretized system is derived as (15)∑l=1naq··l(t)Mjl+∑l=1naql(t)Kjl=-V(t)ηj, j=1,2,…,na which can be rewritten in matrix form as (16)Mq··(t)+Kq(t)=V(t)η where (17)q(t)={q1(t)q2(t):qna(t)}, q··(t)={d2q1(t)dt2d2q2(t)dt2:d2qna(t)dt2}, η={η1η2:ηna}
Assuming a harmonic input voltage to the PZT (hence a harmonic forcing function) in the form of V(t)=vaeiΩt results in harmonic generalized coordinates as (18)q(t)=QeiΩt
Substituting Equation (18) and the harmonic input voltage of V(t)=vaeiΩt into Equation (16) results as (19)Q=va(-MΩ2+K)-1η

For a specific input voltage on the PZT, generalized coordinates of the system will be formulated once the mass, stiffness matrices and vector η are derived. The values of these matrices, as shown in Equation (12), depend on the material properties of the beam, as well as the choice of admissible functions of Xi(x). A good candidate for these functions is the mode shapes of the same cracked beam in the absence of the PZT actuator. These mode shapes are studied in the following section. It is shown that the mode shapes of the cracked beam, as formulated in the reference modeling, are not applicable to our problem and a new approximation of the mode shapes of the cracked beam is introduced.

sec.title: 2.2. Mode shapes of a cracked beam
sec.p:
The admissible functions of Xi(x) of Equation (10) need to satisfy the geometric boundary conditions of the vibrating beam of Figure 1. A reasonable candidate for these functions would be the mode shapes of free vibrations of the cracked beam in the absence of the PZT layer, as shown in Figure 2(a). Figure 2.
Beam (a) with a single fatigue crack and (b) with a single fatigue crack treated as localized stiffness reduction.

There have been several attempts in formulating the closed-form formulations of these mode shapes, as briefly discussed in Section 1. Here, we would start with the most commonly used crack modeling, which is to treat the crack as a localized reduction in the stiffness and to model it as a massless rotational spring at the location of the crack, connecting the two sections of the beam together. The spring is treated as a boundary condition of the two sections of the beam and, by applying the compatibility conditions at the place of the crack and considering the compliance of the spring, closed-form expressions of the mode shapes of the beam are formulated for Euler–Bernoulli beam assumptions.

The stiffness of the resultant rotational spring, kc, is formulated from the strain energy and fracture mechanics formulations as (Dimarogonas, 1996; Tada et al., 2000) (20)Cc=1kc=6hbπEbIbΨ(ac/hb) where Cc is the compliance of the crack, hb is the thickness of the beam, EbIb is the flexural rigidity of the beam away from the crack and ac is the depth of the crack. The values of Ψ for different crack depth ratios of 0≤ac/hb≤0.6 are formulated as (21)Ψ(ac/hb)=0.629(ac/hb)2-1.047(ac/hb)3+4.602(ac/hb)4-9.975(ac/hb)5+20.295(ac/hb)6-32.993(ac/hb)7+47.041(ac/hb)8-40.693(ac/hb)9+19.6(ac/hb)10

Applying the compatibility conditions at the place of the crack, the ith mode shapes of the free vibrations of a cracked beam are formulated as (22)φi(x)=φ1i(x)+CEφ1i″(xc)S2i(x-xc)H(x-xc), 0≤x≤L with the φi(x) function formulated for the simply supported and clamped–clamped beam as (23)Simply Supported:φ1i(x)=D2iS2i(x)+D4iS4i(x), 0≤x<xcClamped-Clamped:φ1i(x)=D3iS3i(x)+D4iS4i(x), 0≤x<xc where D2i, D3i and D4i are constants, CE=EbIbCc and (24)S2i(x)=12λisin(λix)+12λisinh(λix)S3i(x)=-12λi2cos(λix)+12λi2cosh(λix)S4i(x)=-12λi3sin(λix)+12λi3sinh(λix) and the resonant frequency of the beam, Ωi, is formulated as λi4=ρAΩi2/EbIb.
Applying the boundary conditions at the end of the beam to the mode shapes of Equation (22) results in forming the characteristic equation.

This modeling attempt is practical and has been used by many researchers for an Euler–Bernoulli or Timoshenko beam with a uniform cross section and different boundary conditions. It provides closed-form formulations of the mode shapes of the beam as the crack grows and is attractive when the variations in the resonant frequency of the beam due to the presence and growth of the crack are of interest in SHM practice. In the present problem, however, formulated mode shapes of the cracked beam, Equation (22), are to be used as the assumed modes of Equation (10). These mode shapes seem to be a good candidate, as they provide closed-form expressions for modeling of the presence, location and depth of the growing crack.

However, the functions to be used as the assumed mode shapes need to be twice differentiable, which does not apply to the mode shapes of the cracked beam formulated in Equation (22). This is due to the nature of how the presence of the crack in the beam is modeled, that is, the resultant rotational spring and the compatibility of the slope at the place of the crack as (25)φ'2(xc)=φ'1(xc)+EbIbCcφ″1(xc) where φ2(x) represents the mode shapes of the beam at xc<x≤L. The added slope due to the presence of the crack at the location of the crack is part of the crack modeling and could not be avoided in this type of modeling. Therefore, although the mode shapes of the cracked beam as formulated in Equation (22) provide a good model of the cracked beam, they cannot be used in applying the assumed mode approximation and analysis of the complete system of Figure 1. In the following section, a twice-differentiable approximation of the presence of the crack is introduced and compared to the rotational spring modeling of the crack, as presented in Equation (22). These formulated mode shapes can be applied to modeling various problems associated to cracked beams, such as vibration control (in the presence of a PZT actuator) and compensating the effect of variations of the environmental factors in SHM studies (such as temperature variations).

sec.title: 2.3. Approximate modeling of the presence of the crack in a vibrating beam
sec.p: In order to account for the presence of the crack, instead of using the mode shapes of the cracked beam as formulated in the reference modeling, Equation (22), as the assumed mode shapes, the Rayleigh–Ritz approximation is applied in formulating approximate, twice-differentiable mode shapes of the cracked beam.

In the Rayleigh–Ritz method, mode shapes of the vibrating beam are approximated as (26)X(k)(x)=∑i=1nci(k)φi(x) where ci(k) represents the unknown, constant Ritz coefficients and φi(x) represents the admissible functions, satisfying boundary conditions of the system of Figure 2(a). The admissible functions used here are the ith mode shapes of an un-cracked beam with the appropriate boundary conditions, given for simply supported and fixed–fixed boundary conditions as
Simply supported: (27)φi(x)=Disinζixζi=iπL, i=1,2,…,n

Fixed–fixed: (28)φi(x)=Di[(cosζix-coshζix)-cosζiL-coshζiLsinζiL-sinhζiL(sinζix-sinhζix)]cosζiLcoshζiL=1, i=1,2,…,n In the proposed approximation, the crack is still assumed to be treated as a massless rotational spring, with the resultant compliance as given earlier in Equation (20). When using the mode shapes of the un-cracked beam as the admissible functions for Rayleigh–Ritz approximation, the maximum strain energy needs to be modified to account for the loss of energy due to the presence of the crack. This energy loss is proportional to the amount of added flexibility due to the presence of the crack/rotational spring. This may be quantified as the added rotation of the spring, ΔΦi, given by (29)ΔΦi=CcMi=-CEXi″(xc) where Mi is the bending moment of the ith mode of vibrations of the un-cracked beam at the place of the crack and is equivalent to Mi=-EbIbXi″(xc), with Xi″(xc)=d2Xi/dx2|x=xc. The potential energy related to the added rotation of ΔΦi will then be (30)Ucrack=12(ΔΦi)Mi=12EbIbCE(Xi″(xc))2

This energy is proportional to the added compliance due to the presence of the crack and the added rotation, so it needs to be subtracted from the energy of the un-cracked beam in order to formulate the modified stiffness and mass matrices of the Rayleigh–Ritz approximation.

For the beam with a uniform cross section, the maximum strain and kinetic energies of the (k)th mode of the beam after considering the effect of presence of the crack is modified as (31)πmax(k)=12∫0LEbIb[X(k)″(x)]2dx-12EbIbCE[X(k)″(xc)]2Tmax(k)=12ω(k)∫0Lρhbb[X(k)(x)]2dx
Substituting the Rayleigh–Ritz approximation of Equation (26) into Equation (31), these two energies may be expressed as (32)πmax(k)=12c(k)Tkc(k)Tmax(k)=12(ω(k))2cTmc(k)

Based on Equation (32), the modified stiffness and mass matrices for the transverse vibrations of the cracked beam are formulated as (33)kij=∫0LEbIbφi″(x)φj″(x)dx-EbIbCE[φi″(xc)][φj″(xc)]mij=∫0Lρhbbφi(x)φj(x)dx which include the effect of the presence of a growing crack. Equating the maximum strain and kinetic energies of Equation (32) of the system, the problem will be reduced to finding eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the following matrix equation: (34)[k-(ω(k))2m]c(k)=0 where c(k)={c1(k),c2(k),…,cn(k)}T is the vector of Ritz coefficients. Once the c(k) vector is found from Equation (34), it will be substituted into Equation (26) and mode shapes of the cracked beam, X(k)(x), will be approximated.

The idea of modifying the stiffness matrix by including the energy related to the crack was originally presented by Fernandez-Saez et al. (1999) and Rubio and Fernández-Sáez (2010). In their modeling, cracked beam mode shapes of the reference modeling are applied as the admissible functions to a two-term Ritz formulation. The stiffness matrix is modified by adding the potential energy of the crack, Ucrack, in Equation (30) as (35)kijref=∫0xcEbIbφ1i''(x)φ1j''(x)dx+∫xcLEbIbφ1i''(x)φ1j''(x)dx +∫xcLEbIbφ1i''(x)φ1j''(x)dxmijref=∫0xcρhbbφ1i''(x)φ1j''(x)dx+∫xcLρhbbφ2i''(x)φ2j''(x)φ1i(x);0≤x≤xc, φ2i(x);xc<x≤L

It is important to note that when modeling the beam as a bi-section, the presence of the crack as a massless rotational spring is seen at the boundaries of the system. Therefore, the energy of the presence of the crack, Ucrack, will be added to the total energy of the two sections of the beam before and after the crack, as given in Equation (35). Moreover, the approximation of Fernandez-Saez et al., (1999) applies the closed-form expressions of the mode shapes of the cracked beam as given in Equation (22). Hence formulation of the mode shapes of the cracked beam is required in this modeling.

The proposed approximation method is beneficial as there is no need for formulating the mode shapes of the cracked beam as given in the reference modeling approach. The only crack-related parameter needed is its compliance, Cc, which is easily formulated as Equation (20) as a function of size of the crack. It will be shown later in Section 3 that applying the proposed approximation instead of the Fernandez-Saez et al. (1999) approximation will not impose a significant error to the results of the crack modeling. In other words, the proposed modeling effort provides a close approximation of the mode shapes of a cracked beam without any further closed-form formulations of the mode shapes of the beam as given in the reference modeling.

In order to quantify the accuracy of the proposed approximation for the mode shapes of the cracked beam, a numerical study is done before continuing to apply these approximate mode shapes for modeling the complete structure of Figure 1. In the following section, vibratory characteristics (in particular, resonant frequencies) of an Euler–Bernoulli beam with specific dimensions and two boundary conditions and no PZT patch are compared for two different modeling approaches of (a) the reference modeling with the mode shapes given in Equation (22) and (b) the proposed approximation of using the Rayleigh–Ritz method and the matrices of Equation (33).

sec.title: 2.3.1. Numerical study on the proposed approximation
sec.p:
The beam considered in the numerical analysis is assumed to be made of aluminum with the dimensions of length of 30.48 cm (12″), width of 2.54 cm (1″) and thickness of 0.32 cm (1/8″), as shown in Figure 3. Mass density and modulus of elasticity of the beam are assumed to be constant and equal to 2770 kg/m3 (0.10 lb/in3) and 71.7 GPa (10.4 Mpsi), respectively (Shigley et al., 2004). Two boundary conditions of simply supported and fixed–fixed are considered in the numerical studies of free vibrations of the beam. Figure 3.
Schematic of the beam used in the numerical studies.

The characteristic equation of free vibrations of the cracked, simply supported or fixed at both ends beam of Figure 3 may be analytically formulated following the reference modeling approach (approach (a)). Substituting the material properties and beam dimensions into the characteristic equation, the wavelength and resonant frequencies of the free vibrations of the beam may be numerically calculated for different crack lengths and positions along the beam. For each depth and position of the crack, the modeling approach proposed in the present paper is used for approximating the resonant frequencies of the free vibrations of the beam. These frequencies of the first three modes of vibrations versus the crack position along the beam are plotted in Figures 4–6 and compared for the two modeling approaches. In order to have a better picture of the results, graphs for only two crack depth ratios of ac/hb=0.2 and ac/hb=0.4 are shown in these figures. In these graphs (a) the round dotted line represents frequencies of the reference modeling approach for a crack depth ratio of ac/hb=0.2, (b) the dashed line represents frequencies of the proposed modeling approach for a crack depth ratio of ac/hb=0.2, (c) the solid line represents frequencies of the reference modeling approach for a crack depth ratio of ac/hb=0.4 and (d) the solid-square line represents frequencies of the proposed modeling approach for a crack depth ratio of ac/hb=0.4. Figure 4.
Resonant frequency of the first mode of the beam versus the crack position along the beam for (a) simply supported and (b) fixed–fixed boundary conditions. The round dotted line and dashed line represent reference and proposed modeling for ac/hb=0.2, respectively. The solid line and solid-square line represent reference and proposed modeling for ac/hb=0.4, respectively.
Figure 5.
Resonant frequency of the second mode of the beam versus crack position along the beam for (a) simply supported and (b) fixed–fixed boundary conditions. The round dotted line and dashed line represent reference and proposed modeling for ac/hb=0.2, respectively. The solid line and solid-square line represent reference and proposed modeling for ac/hb=0.4, respectively. Figure 6.
Resonant frequency of the third mode of the beam versus crack position along the beam for (a) simply supported and b) fixed–fixed boundary conditions. The round dotted line and dashed line represent reference and proposed modeling for ac/hb=0.2, respectively. The solid line and solid-square line represent reference and proposed modeling for ac/hb=0.4, respectively.

The values of approximated resonance frequencies of the beam, using the proposed modeling approach, are compared to the ones calculated using the reference model; the amount of error percentage is given in Table 1. These values are the maximum error percentages for all crack positions along the length of the beam which happen at the extrema of graphs of Figures 4–6. These extrema are the extrema of the bending moment of the mode shapes of the un-cracked beam. Hence, if a crack is located at these positions, with extrema in the second derivative of the un-cracked beam, the effect of crack on the resonance frequencies of the beam is the maximum, according to both modeling attempts (Equations (22) and (33)). Table 1 gives the error percentage for three crack depth ratios of 0.2, 0.4 and 0.6. The modeling of a crack as a rotational spring with the resultant compliance of the crack, as formulated in Equation (20), is applicable to crack depth ratios of ac/b≤0.6, with a 0.2% accuracy (Tada et al., 2000). The crack depth ratio of 0.6 is, therefore, chosen to find the maximum possible error between the two modeling approaches. The error for the two crack depth ratios of 0.2 and 0.4 are also presented for discussing the accuracy of the proposed approximation as the crack grows.

It is shown in Table 1 that for the crack depth ratio of 0.2, the two modeling approaches match well, with a very small error percentage of less that 0.06% for all crack locations and support conditions for the first three vibration modes. The error percentage increases as the crack grows in depth, yet for the crack depth ratio of 0.4 remains less than 0.15% for all crack locations, except for the ends of a fixed beam. The percentage of the error for the crack located at the ends of a fixed beam is the highest for all modes and crack depth ratios, as shown in Table 1. The effect of the presence of the crack on the resonance frequency of a fixed beam is also the highest when the crack is located at the ends of the beam. This is due to the fact that if a crack is located at the ends of a fixed–fixed beam, as the crack grows, the presence of the crack changes the boundary conditions of the beam. In other words, as the crack grows at one of the ends of a fixed–fixed beam, support conditions of the beam alter more towards the fixed–free conditions. This shift in the support conditions drastically changes the mode shapes of the un-cracked beam. Therefore, the initial choice of mode shapes of a fixed–fixed beam for the Rayleigh–Ritz approximation results in higher errors when the crack is located at the ends of the beam. The effect of the presence of the crack at the ends of a fixed beam is higher, because this effect is proportional to the bending moment of the beam at the location of the crack. At the location of a fixed support, this bending moment is nonzero. As the crack grows, however, the support conditions at the cracked end become more similar to a free end with zero bending moments. Therefore, the amount of the second derivative of the mode shapes changes at the place of the crack if the growing crack is located near one of the ends of a fixed–fixed beam. This is not the case for a simply supported beam due to the fact that a pinned and a free end of the beam both imply a zero bending moment at the support. Therefore, a change in the support condition from pinned to free does not have an effect on the second derivative of the beam mode shapes and hence on the resonant frequency of the cracked beam.

For the third mode of vibrations, other than the crack located at the ends of the fixed beam, the approximation error is small for all crack locations and beam supports and is much less than 2%. Therefore, except for the crack located at the ends of a fixed–fixed beam, the proposed modeling approach is numerically shown to result in a very small error percentage for crack depth ratios of less than 0.6 and the first three vibration modes. For higher modes of vibration, numerical analysis shows that the error percentage of the natural frequencies of the first five modes for the simply supported and fixed–fixed beams is similar to that of the first three modes given in Table 1. It is also seen that there is a good correlation between the calculated frequencies of both modeling approaches for a simply supported beam at mode numbers higher than five. For a fixed–fixed beam, however, the accuracy of the proposed modeling decreases as the error percentage becomes large for mode numbers higher than five.

Having shown, numerically, that the approximated resonance frequencies of a cracked beam using the proposed modeling approach matches with those of the reference cracked beam modeling with only a small error, this modeling approach is applied in formulating the mode shapes of the cracked beam with a surface-bonded PZT layer, presented in the following section. It is important to mention again that the usefulness of using the proposed modeling approach in approximating twice-differentiable mode shapes of the cracked beam over the reference modeling of Equation (35) is that there is no need to have the closed-form expressions of the mode shapes of the beam formulated beforehand.

sec.title: 3. Numerical results
sec.p:
The beam considered in the numerical analysis is assumed to be made of aluminum with the same dimensions and material properties of Section 2.3.1. The beam considered in the numerical studies, here, is actuated by a surface-bonded PZT actuator, as shown in Figure 7. Figure 7.
Schematic of the cracked beam with the piezoceramic actuator considered in the numerical studies.

In the first part of the numerical analysis, for a fixed position and length of the PZT patch, mode shapes of the cracked beam with the inactive PZT layer are formulated, using the Rayleigh–Ritz method and applying the proposed crack modeling of Section 2.3. Having these mode shapes formulated, they will be used as the assumed mode for formulating the temporal equation of the vibrations of the complete system of the PZT-driven cracked beam. Two different boundary conditions of simply supported and fixed–fixed are considered for the beam.

After formulating the temporal equation and the forcing vector for the PZT actuator, the effect of varying different design parameters of length and location of the PZT are studied for the optimal placement of the actuator. The surface-bonded PZT patch is assumed to be of the same width as the beam (i.e. 2.54 cm). The effect of growth and position of the crack on the forcing function is also discussed in the following numerical analysis. This is applicable to optimizing the PZT actuator placement in damage monitoring in SHM applications.

sec.title: 3.1. PZT-driven vibrations of the cracked Euler–Bernoulli beam of Figure 7
sec.p: The first three mode shapes of the cracked beam of Figure 7 (without the PZT) are approximated for different crack positions and depths and for the two support conditions of fixed–fixed and simply supported, as explained in Section 2.2. These mode shapes and the associated resonant frequencies (as shown in Figures 4–6) vary for different crack specifications. These approximate mode shapes of the cracked beam are then used in formulating the temporal equation of the vibrations of the PZT-driven cracked beam. Assuming a harmonic input voltage to the PZT (hence a harmonic forcing function) with the frequency of Ω, generalized coordinates of q(t)={q1(t),q2(t),…,qna(t)}T are formulated as given in Equation (18) and rewritten here: (36)q(t)=QeiΩt with (37)Q=va(-MΩ2+K)-1η as presented in Section 2.1. The optimal placement of the PZT actuator depends on the forcing vector of η formulated in Equation (12) and rewritten here as (38)ηi=∫x1ax2aJpXi″(x)dx

Depending on the formulated mode shapes of the cracked beam, length (La=x2a-x1a) and position (x1a) of the PZT actuator can be chosen in a way that one or more modes of vibration are actuated or suppressed the most. An optimization study can be done for the actuation-forcing vector versus both factors of the length and location of the PZT actuator along the length of the beam, which is done by optimizing the value of ∫x1ax2aXi″(x)dx for all possible choices of x1a (i.e. 0≤x1a≤L-La) and for different lengths of the PZT. This optimization is applicable to vibration control of the cracked beam, as well as compensation of temperature (or other environmental factors) variations in SHM studies.

According to the formulations of Equation (12), mass and stiffness matrices are different for each crack length and each crack position. The actuation-forcing vector of η→ also depends on two independent parameters of PZT location (x1a) and length (La). Therefore, changing each of these four parameters will alter at least one of the elements of the generalized coordinates of the system, as shown in Equations (36) and (37), and will result in a different function for the beam deflection. Depending on the application of the PZT actuation (e.g. vibration suppression of specific modes), the two PZT-related factors may be varied to achieve the desired forcing vector. These factors may be varied in order to formulate the optimal placement of the PZT actuator with respect to the specific application and regarding the growing crack located along the length of the beam.

Here, in the first part of the numerical analysis, the effect of placement of a PZT actuator with a fixed length is studied on the actuation forcing for the first three modes of vibrations of a cracked beam. It is assumed that the crack position and depth are fixed. As discussed earlier, the effect of PZT-dependant design parameters on the forcing vector of η is seen through the values of the integral A2d=∫x1ax2aXi″(x)dx. Therefore, in the numerical studies presented in this section, values of this integral (A2d) are studied when considering the actuator placement. In the next two parts of the numerical analysis, the effect of the two parameters of the crack length and depth and the forcing function are studied separately.

sec.title: 4. Conclusions
sec.p: The presence of a surface-bonded PZT actuator affects the vibratory response of a structure due to the added mass, stiffness and the electro-mechanical coupling between the PZT patches and the structure. In order to have a more complete modeling of a SHM system, the effects of a PZT actuator, as well as that of a growing crack, were analytically modeled for a vibrating Euler–Bernoulli beam. It was shown that in order to combine the effect of a growing crack and the PZT actuator together, common closed-form formulations of the mode shapes of the cracked beam (bi-sectional beam connected with a rotational spring) are not applicable as they are not twice differentiable. A new approximate formulation of the mode shapes of the cracked beam was introduced here by applying the Rayleigh–Ritz method. The effect of the presence and growth of the crack on the vibratory response of the beam was modeled through formulating the loss of energy due to the presence of the crack, approximated here as a massless rotational spring. The proposed approximate mode shapes of the cracked beam and the associated resonant frequencies were numerically compared to that of the reference modeling of the cracked beam with two different support conditions of fixed–fixed and simply supported. It was shown that the proposed crack modeling provides a close approximation of the mode shapes of the cracked beam with a very small error percentage. The analysis presented here will be beneficial to other modeling approaches, as it provides twice-differentiable mode shapes for the cracked beam. Moreover, the proposed modeling effort was shown to provide a close approximation of the mode shapes of a cracked beam without any further closed-form formulations of the mode shapes of the beam as required in previously published works.

The mode shapes of a cracked beam formulated in the proposed modeling approach were then applied to the PZT-actuated vibrations of the beam using the assumed mode and the Rayleigh–Ritz methods. Different design parameters of length and location of the PZT actuator along the length of the beam were studied numerically for the optimal placement of the actuator in the sense of the forcing vector. The effect of a growing crack at different locations along the length of the beam was also studied numerically for a fixed position and length of the PZT actuator. The optimization of the PZT actuator placement is applicable to vibration control, in the sense of vibration suppressions or amplifications, as well as in damage monitoring in the SHM applications.
